review:
Assassin's Creed Unity remains by far one of the most astoundingly beautiful and visually appealing games I've ever played, even now, 5 years down the line. With minimal bugs (at least in the version I have), it truly brings out the streets of Paris and the atmosphere of the Revolution in an amazing way. 

With regards to the story, I believe it could have been done much better. I was really into it in the beginning few sequences, but it got to be a bit of a drag later on. The storyline with Bellec, especially, I think was a missed opportunity, not to mention that it could have made the Assassin-Templar struggle more immersed and intertwined with the Revolution itself. I was especially disappointed that the story didn't really involve Napoleon too much, and that Arno didn't really seem to have any growth, except into a cocky prick with a chip on his shoulder.

Regarding the gameplay itself, there are aspects I enjoyed and those I hated. I'm personally a fan of the return to the single hidden blade, and I loved how it could only really be used for executions, much like in the original Assassin's Creed. I loved the fact that they scaled up the combat difficulty, which meant that you had no choice but to be extremely judicious and tactical in how you approached conflict. I'm not a fan of the stealth mechanics, however, since there are some things from the older games that you cannot do in this one, like carrying corpses around, whistling from hiding spots, and such, which really made for frustrating gameplay. The fact that your enemies couldn't parkour like you could seemed to be very fitting, since I can't really imagine gendarme and soldiers clambering across the Paris rooftops, all the while carrying their muskets, axes and such. The parkour was an absolute joy, though I think they could have refined it a lot more. This was the most buggy aspect of my game, and it felt quite clunky, taking away from the entire immersiveness. The sheer number of chests in the game is really unnecessary, and it was a chore to hunt them all down. 

All this being said, I did enjoy the game, and I'd recommend it as a buy. Besides, it's dirt cheap on steam, anyway, so you'll get a value for your money whatever your personal impressions of the game

review: The  last Assassin's Creed game I played was 2 on my Xbox 360, so I haven't really kept up on all the new gameplay changes and whatnot. But I loved this game. At the time of the review, I am on the last mission and then gotta do the DLC. The movement in this game is the most fluid movement I have seen in an Assassin's Creed game. (While I didn't play any of the others really, I did see gameplay for most of them.) I am also a huge sound snob, and the sound design for this game is fantastic. Everything from the sword clashes to the foot steps while running through the streets of Paris sounded amazing. And speaking of Paris, the city itself is very beautiful. It is also so lively. I'm not sure if this is a new mechanic or was added in in an earlier game, but also having the Crowd Events to deal with while you are running around the city is very fun and immersive in my opinion. I find it very fun to be running down a street, crowd event triggers, quick run assassination, then continue running. I usually loot the bad guys, but sometimes I just skip that. Overall the game is very very fun, and I highly recommend it. As for bugs, the worst one I ran into was simply some patrolling or running thieves/enemies getting caught on crowds when trying to walk/run through them. I was able to walk through them just fine myself. But with the amount of people walking around the streets, you are bound to run into people getting stuck on each other from time to time. Great game, and got me back into Assassin's Creed again.

review:
tl;dr: Definetely recommend.

I bought this game on sale alongside all the other games of the franchise and to be honest I wasn't expecting much of it since it gets destroyed by critics since release. Turns out Unity became my favorite AC game. 

The parkour here is the best in the series, smooth and stylish, although some may find it a bit unrealistic; Arno may not be the best main character from the series, but he's definetely stylish, charming and goes through a lot of stuff, which made me get personally attached to him.

This game, in my opinion, is the one I feel the most true Assassin vibes from, it's so much fun to stealth in this game. I don't know about release, but RIGHT NOW the game is pretty solid and still has bugs, but minimal ones, it doesn't ruin anything, people should stop crying so much. Plus, the Co-op and Heist features are a plus here, really fun to play and unique.

Story is kind of bland, wouldn't say it's great, but it's not bad either, it's alright since it's not the strong point of this game. Plus, Dead Kings DLC is pretty fun, one of my favorites. Definetely recommend this, even if you have to buy it.

review:
Well, Assassin's Creed Unity is an Assassin's Creed game, with everything it implies in great settings and totally assisted but still frustratingly imprecise gameplay.
So I won't do a review of every Assassin's Creed game here and will just focus on the particularities of Unity.

Nobody seemed to like Unity, but I actually did. :p
The mistake most players did was to buy the game at release (or even worse in pre-release), when AC2 and AC3 already showed us that every big AC release is rushed and buggy. The good news is that this time was so bad that they actually decided to correct it. So if you play Unity today, you'll get to enjoy a relatively bug-free game with a far better optimized engine.

Unity is still a very standard AC game. The changes are minimal. I think the biggest for me was the openness of most situations. Your targets are in a huge building with many entries and options, making for a more Dishonored-feel to the assassintations.
I must admit that I played this game two or three years after my previous AC game mostly because I needed to update my PC. And so I wasn't to fed up with the AC gameplay. I had kinda missed it. I don't know if I would have enjoyed Unity this much if I just finished my previous AC.

There's actually something that changed from previous AC games, it's the depiction of female characters. The main character is still male (and particularly uninteresting here), but I felt that the teams behind made everything possible to showcase as many interesting female characters as possible. You'll note that half the assassins helping you in the street are female and they fight exactly in the same way as males.
It's too bad Unity got that controversy about sexism in video games when every previous title in the series should have gotten it, but it only happened when the developpers actually tried to make things better.
It would have make things better if the playable character was Elise (who is the actual main character of the story), but I guess the communication department of Ubisoft again enforced their views on the actual productive teams.

review: After reading reviews I was concerned about bugs, but I have played the whole game including DLC and it only crashed once. I played all the previous ACs and enjoyed them, but I enjoyed this one the least so far. I general it was because there is nothing new really. For me Black Flag and Rogue were great because of the ship which added an extra dimension. Unity went back to the old formula and it felt stale. The graphics are great but they don't make up for the resulting problems in gameplay. I like stealth games and it is irritating to be forced into combat when I have Arno stand by a wall, press "cover" again and again but he refuses to do so. As a player of the AC games I am used to feeling like a puppet master who realises that the strings are all tangled, but Unity is one of the worst - trying to get Arno to go through a window can be truly difficult. Then there's the kill animation and the camera angles - how did the designers get it so wrong? I can't help feeling that there was insufficient play testing during development. Or maybe the bugs that they did fix were really so bad that they ended up feeling like the game was finished. It is finished as in complete, but it lacks the quality in playability that it deserves. I think it is the weakest of the AC games. As a result I'm likely to wait a long time before I play Syndicate because it really will have to be a good sale price for be to buy it.

review:
Assassin's Creed Unity is a unique experience. I've never encountered a game with such a strong sense of time and place. You really feel like you're pushing your way through rioters in 18th century France, in a way that books and movies can't replicate.

review:
I really don't understand all the negativity around this game. Hands down, easily the most beautiful and wholesome Assassin's Creed game to date. Does it glitch? Yeah.. A little.. It's not game breaking, though. But what about the positives? 

1. Absolutely beautiful story. Arno is a very lovable character, so is Elise. Both of them will leave a long lasting impression on you. 

2. The graphics are gorgeous and the music is captivating. 

3. The atmosphere is stunning. Paris is huge, crowded, bustling and it feels alive. Something I haven't felt in an AC game for a long time.

4. Gameplay has been completely revamped. Enemies are less predictable in combat, mis-timing blows WILL lead to punishment, and you can no longer single handedly take down an entire army. You WILL die. They WILL swarm you. Oh, and good luck running away from angry guards. They'll shoot you down without hesitation. Stealth had been made more gratifying. Enemies are a lot more alert, and they WILL detect you if you do something stupid. And if you're detected by one, all of god friends will come to his aid. Detection can be deadly. Simply put, the new gameplay makes combat fun and rewarding, it also makes stealth essential, not superfluous.

5. The game is full of activity and it took me well over 100 hours to complete up to a reasonable percentage. You never get bored. Money well spent. Even at full price. 

All in all, bugs aside, this game is not one to miss.

review:
Okay, this game.. this game has issues to state it mildly.. But, hear me out here, I liked it despite that.

The main character is an unlikable P.O.S. who never gains a personality other than a grumpy(read annoying).

The combat is clunky. Like original AC games where you stand around and parry the 14 guys who stand around and occasionally jab at you, except this time you can use a pickaxe as a weapon.. and its badass

The game is buggy and crashes constantly. It sucks less than it did when it came out I think, kinda.

You can pick and choose outfits and colors and really make your assassin hideous, my character had a floppy hood tail and was BRIGHT red.. he was mega disgusting and I loved him. OH, and you look like that in all cutscenes.. its hilarious.

The multiplayer/co-op is trash. that's all

The setting was fun, the running around in Paris was extremely enjoyable compared to the previous games which all had fairly small low to the ground housing and the occasional tower or whatever, Paris feels big and dangerous.

It's a solid 7.5/10, the pickaxe really made this one of my favorite AC games.. seriously laughed way too many times walking through cutscenes as a "serious assassin" dressed as a bright red clown.

I much prefer this style of gameplay though to the RPG heavy origins and odyssey and hope they return to this form in the future.

review:
A good Assassin's Creed game. I had initially tried it on PS4, but the loading times drove me crazy, especially when you had to simply reload a checkpoint. The experience was much more enjoyable on PC.
The context of Revolutionary France is particularly interesting, as well as the storyline and characters. It's always enjoyable to meet all these great historical figures and interact with them.
The game does have its technical issues. It ran very smoothly on my machine, but the pop-ins grow into a distraction. I didn't notice too much at first, but then when I did, it started bothering me. What has been seen cannot be unseen. All of a sudden, you see how objects appear out of thin air, dresses and hats appear magically on bystanders as you approach them. I once even approached a "librairie" only to see it transform into a "boucherie" before my very eyes. Walking back would turn it into "librairie" again.
Other than that, the game still looks rather pretty, and Parisian architecture and monuments certainly help.
There are tons of collectibles and side quests for people with OCD, though sometimes it can be over the top. Having to replay co-op missions three times to unlock every reward was just plain silly, other missions such as the Companion Missions, felt entirely unnecessary.
It truly is a pleasure to parkour through the streets of Paris, though every now and then you get into a ridiculous situation where your character, instead of just running forward, decides he's going to jump on a chair. Trying to get him off the chair will make him jump and grab onto a lamp post, then onto a low railing that's 3 feet off the ground, and it's just painful and cringy to watch, especially if you're in the middle of a chase.
I don't believe the game has much replay value, and I don't even feel like trying the DLC, but you still get bang for your buck when it's on sale at a very low price, if you didn't grab it when it was free after the Notre-Dame fire.

review:
I'll say straight away that this Paris is one of the best cities ever in gaming. It's an absolute masterpiece and an achievement. It's then a pitty and a massive disapointment seeing how this game doesn't know how to use it to it's full potential. Gameplay and game design completely destroy a game that could have been something special.

Also the story falls short of what could have been, Arno and Elise are likable protagonists, but the story itself is uninteresting, boring and predictable, which is a shame cause the French Revolution is one of the most fascinating and gripping periods in history ever and should have been used in a better way.

I'll still recomend it, but just because of Paris, it's atmosphere and the fantastic visuals for a 5 year old game.

Oh, and play it French for max immersion :D

review: Not only did they make an amazing gesture with the Notre Dame disaster by donating money to the reconstruction and the free copies they sold, but the game itself is the core of what Assassins Creed represents, in the good, by making the best parkour so far in the series, the great coop missions to have fun with your friends,the stealth system, which is improved by a lot thanks to a lot of new tools (but without whistling, why ubi) and the beauty of the city of Paris but also in the bad parts, like the typical following up random people, repetitive side missions or the new combat system which is different from older games, but still not as challenging (imo) or fun as other games in the market. On release this game was a disaster, with so many bugs that made this game hated and feared with the bad reviews, but after the patches Unity has almost to no bugs (my PC doesnt  its a must buy if you are a fan pf the AC saga, and very worth buying even if youre not into the saga very much. Ubisoft may be a company that its hard to think that is just good or just bad they made a lot of mistakes, bugs, downgrades and bad games, but also if they work hard like in this game (post patches of course) they make amazing products worth buying. The gesture of Notre Dame and the very good game  itself deserves a positive review.

Great and immersive game, even five years on! Wandering Paris is such a pleasant thrill and pushing your way through the crowds is something I've really missed in a few of the more recent games. It's far from perfect, but it's just too much fun that you can generally ignore a few of its shortcomings (namely the Helix system, the lack of an interactive Modern framing, etc, but, whatever!) and fully enjoy the game for what it is.

Oh, and you can climb Notre Dame - though I am mildly annoyed that they put the 19th Century tower in there, as iconic as it is to the structure these days, it wasn't there in 1798!

review:
A lot of people says it's bad and a lot more says is good, which side do I choose? Well I'm on the good review side, for me generally the concept of being a Assassin was all I needed to love this game, it didn't matter to me if I was only doing missions that were point to point, it didn't matter how little amount of things I could do beside missions, or how parts of the story didn't exactly match up with real history and I don't think that is very important anyway since this game isn't to educate you but to entertain you. So if all you kinda cared about was being an Assassin like me then is more than enough. 

However, just because I could be a Assassin and already loving the game at that point really isn't enough to earn a thumbs up since AC allows you to upgrade your skills and Unity specialty is multiplayer so combined those two together for me is more than enough for a thumbs up. Sorry if this review wasn't helpful to you or allowed you to understand the game more but this is my honest opinion.

review:
Assassin‚Äôs Creed Unity is a game of impossible peaks and disappointing valleys. Its highs of movement, customization options, and just the city of Paris itself pierce the sky like the spire of Notre Dame. On a purely technical level, Unity is a marvel to walk through and admire. But at the same time, a lot of my journey through the French Revolution felt as cold and heartless as the darkest depths of the catacombs. I was never given a real reason to care about new Assassin Arno, or the events that transpired. Instead, I had to find my own fun throughout my 30 hours in Unity, which was generally easy to do in its large sandbox assassination scenarios. However, it‚Äôs a bit disappointing to see how few of the long-standing problems with the series have been solved by the upgrade to the new generation of gaming hardware.
Each of the various districts unfolds with its own sense of character and environmental storytelling, from the ornate palaces of the privileged, to back-alleys running with the blood of the revolutionaries. But what makes it really unique and distinct from past games is its citizens, who form some of the largest, most impressive crowds I've ever encountered. 
The disgruntled masses make it even more of a necessity to scurry along rooftops instead of the streets, and thankfully, this mode of transportation does not disappoint. Most of the time, traversal in Unity feels better than ever thanks to fantastic animations, buildings with plenty of climbable paths, and a new downward parkour system that adds certain finesse to the act of shimming down a wall, resolving one of my big gripes with previous AC games.

review:
I was actually surprised at how much I like this game. I didn't like any of the games set in the American colonies because they lacked the very thing I loved about the earlier Creed titles. That is the gorgeous iconic buildings situated in the legendary cities of the Old World. I didn't buy this title when it came out because of the technical problems but I haven't encountered any glitches at all in the current version. 
I don't know how they managed to fill the streets with so many NPC's, many more than the newer games. It really brings the city to life. It's really sad that the game's release was blighted by technical problems because it really is an exceptional achievement. I would have paid full price for the game in it's current state so anyone getting this free really scored. I may even go back and try to finish Black Flag.

review: To me this was the best and probably still is the best AC to come out yet. Unfortunately there were some limitation issues and perhaps some coding issues they ran into that still leaves npc's randomly changing outfits consistently, so it hasn't been received well. However, if you can get past the unfortunate issues it still has in it, there is a top notch AC game here with superior climbing and all around movement mechanics; amazing world design; unique for it's time leveling system (at least in this series); and one of the best stories thus far. I HIGHLY recommend this game and hope they aren't sticking with the annoyingly "souls like" wannabe mechanics they are using in ACO and ACO lol.
